body:
@NSProgrammer - You opened in issue in the past which mentioned Brotli [1]. Do you have support for it and would you be interested in submitting this to Netty?

[1] https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/6784

@Scottmitch I was under the impression that Brotli was slow on compressing and fast on decompressing, so the typical use case was to compress offline and serve already compressed content, not compress on the fly. I guess that's what @NSProgrammer was trying to achieve.

I'm not sure it's worth trying to support on the server/compression side. On the contrary, it could be interesting to support on the client/side decompression. In the Java world, there's currently 2 decompressors:
* [Official Java decoder](https://github.com/google/brotli/tree/master/java/org/brotli/dec) implementation
* [JBrotli](https://github.com/MeteoGroup/jbrotli) JNI wrapper

Last time I checked, the former was nowhere as fast as the latter. I guess it's intended for Android. Then, the former is JNI based, so here be dragons...

Note the latest cool kid in the compression game is FB's [Zstandard](https://github.com/facebook/zstd).

I clarified the title. The intention was to investigate supporting Brotli decompression/compression and not just compression.

However these things generally depend upon the content being compressed and the configuration of the compressor. Certain configuration levels of Brotli can actually provide a favorable throughput/compression ratio compared to gzip [1]. As always the advise would be "benchmark for your data", but before benchmarking can be done we must first support Brotli.

[1] https://blogs.akamai.com/2016/02/understanding-brotlis-potential.html

I'm going to defer to Ben Leib for Netty integration convos (I can't find his github account to @ mention him).

I will say that we've measured a bunch and do think that with the 12 levels of compression for brotli that some of those levels are efficient enough to run on-demand in servers with native code (Java implementations just can't hack it).   There are definitely diminishing returns on smaller payloads and it is prudent to test at which point Brotli should kick in over gzip.  gzip/deflate are fast, clearly, but for large enough payloads, the latency of encoding is surpassed by the reduction in payload translating fewer TCP window round-trips needing to be sent.

(Ben Leib here)

We have implemented both Brotli and Zstandard compression of on-demand REST API responses, but we ended up doing it at a higher level in the stack. This was faster for me largely just due to my being less familiarity with Netty code, but also because as @NSProgrammer mentions the Java implementation was too slow and pulling the JNI implementation into Netty looked iffy.

FWIW we have found that for larger payloads (over about 10kB), the payload size reduction from using Brotli or Zstandard instead of gzip outweighed the longer compression time in terms of improving client-perceived latency, especially over slower networks.

Our benchmarking also made Brotli look slightly more performant than Zstandard without a dictionary for an equivalent compression ratio, but YMMV.
thanks ~~@bfritz~~ @bgleib  ... is there any interest in doing this at the Netty level and making a PR contribution?
